paper_id: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments

paper_metadata.title: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Potassium balance and dynamics in soil under different long-term fertilization treatments in agricultural systems.

research_methodology.experimental_design: A long-term stationary field experiment with a three-crop rotation (potatoes, winter wheat, spring barley), where all three crops were grown each year. The trial comprised 6 fertilization treatments.

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Soil samples were taken at the start of the experiment in 1996 and at the end of the 7th crop rotation in 2017. Plant yields were measured every year.
temporal_scope.seasonal_coverage: Fertilizers were applied in autumn or spring depending on the crop and fertilizer type. Harvests were conducted at maturity.

monitoring_timeline.event: Experiment establishment and initial soil sampling
Final soil sampling after 7th crop rotation

spatial_scope.geographic_coverage: Two sites with different soil-climatic conditions in the Czech Republic: Hněvčeves and Humpolec.

site_characteristics.climate: Mean annual temperature 8.2 °C, mean annual precipitation 573 mm

site_characteristics.soil_type: Stagnic Cambisol on loess on paragneiss
site_characteristics.climate: Mean annual temperature 7.0 °C, mean annual precipitation 665 mm

spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: The crop rotation used corresponds well with intensive farming systems in the Czech Republic.

sample_design.randomization_approach: Not specified, but typical for long-term stationary experiments.

controls_and_treatments.name: FYM 1/2
controls_and_treatments.description: Half dose of farmyard manure + nitrogen in mineral fertilizers.

controls_and_treatments.name: N + St
controls_and_treatments.description: Straw of spring barley + N in mineral nitrogen fertilizers.

measurement_protocols.method: Dry decomposition followed by atomic adsorption spectrometry.
CaCl2/DTPA extraction (0.01 mol/L CaCl2 and 0.002 mol/L DTPA), shaken for 1 hour.
Mehlich 3 extraction (0.02 mol/L CH3COOH, 0.25 mol/L NH4NO3, 0.015 mol/L NH4F, 0.013 mol/L HNO3, 0.001 mol/L EDTA), shaken for 5 minutes.
Ammonium acetate extraction (1 mol/L NH4OAc at pH 7.00), shaken for 2 hours.
Boiling 1 mol/L HNO3 extraction for 10 minutes.
Calculated by subtracting NH4OAc-extractable K from boiling HNO3-extractable K.

instrumentation.instrument: Inductively Coupled Plasma - Optical Emission Spectrometer

quality_control: Soil samples were air-dried and sieved (≤ 2 mm).
Soil analyses were performed on samples from plots with spring barley.

statistical_approach.significance_testing: Differences among variants were tested for statistical significance. Pearson's correlation coefficient was used.
statistical_approach.uncertainty_quantification: Data in figures are presented with letters indicating statistically significant differences.

primary_measurements.measurement_context: Table 3. Balance calculated as inputs minus outputs (crop uptake) for the period 1996-2017.
Figure 1. Average values across all treatments in 2017. Statistically significant differences were recorded among individual variants at both sites.
Figure 2. Average values across all treatments in 2017. Significantly lowest contents at variants without K fertilization.
Figure 3. Average values across all treatments in 2017.
Figure 4. Values in 2017. Significant differences between sites. Significant tendency to decrease at Hněvčeves on variants without K fertilization. No significant impact of fertilization at Humpolec.
Table 4. Average values across all treatments in 2017.
Average values over the experiment duration.

statistical_relationships.significance_level: Not specified, but correlation is high.

temporal_patterns.trend_description: In variants without K fertilization, the amount of K in the plough layer decreased over the 21-year period. The highest decrease was recorded at the variant with mineral N fertilization only.

At the Hněvčeves site, a significant tendency to decrease the non-exchangeable K content was observed at the variants without K fertilization. At the Humpolec site, 21 years of different fertilization did not have a significant impact on the changes of non-exchangeable K.
temporal_patterns.trend_significance: Significant at Hněvčeves, not significant at Humpolec.

comparative_results.practical_significance: Non-exchangeable K content was ~3.7 times higher at Humpolec (avg 3000 mg/kg) than at Hněvčeves (avg 850 mg/kg), indicating a much larger K reserve.
The recovery rate of potassium by crops was 24–26% from farmyard manure and 27–52% from mineral fertilizers.

At Hněvčeves, Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc extracted ~19% of HNO3-K, while CAT extracted ~10%. At Humpolec, Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc extracted ~5%, while CAT extracted ~4%. This shows different extraction efficiencies depending on soil type.

geographic_details.elevation: Hněvčeves: 265 m a.s.l.; Humpolec: 525 m a.s.l.

soil_properties.soil_classification: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol; Humpolec: Stagnic Cambisol
soil_properties.texture: Hněvčeves: Clay loam; Humpolec: Sandy loam
soil_properties.mineralogy: Parent material at Hněvčeves is loess. Parent material at Humpolec is loess on paragneiss. The paper suggests clay mineral type is more important than total clay content.

cropping_systems: Intensive farming system with a three-crop rotation.
land_use_context.historical_context: The experiment was established in 1996 on agricultural soils.

growth_stages_studied: Full cycle to maturity for yield and uptake measurements.

production_metrics.K uptake: Total K removed in harvested products over 21 years, detailed in Table 3.

rates.NPK_treatment: P: 30 kg/ha, K: 100 kg/ha for wheat and barley. N: 140 kg/ha for wheat, 70 kg/ha for barley.
rates.FYM_treatment: Hněvčeves: 63.0 t/ha/3 years; Humpolec: 59.45 t/ha/3 years. Nutrient content varied.
rates.N_only_treatment: N: 140 kg/ha for wheat, 70 kg/ha for barley, 120 kg/ha for potatoes.

timing: Organic fertilizers (FYM, straw) applied in autumn to potatoes.
Mineral P and K applied to each crop in autumn.
Mineral N applied in spring for potatoes and barley; split application for winter wheat (BBCH 21 and BBCH 31-32).

input_rates.K_input: Ranged from 0 to 2674 kg K/ha over 21 years depending on treatment and site (Table 3).

output_measurements.K_uptake: Ranged from 1124 to 2452 kg K/ha over 21 years depending on treatment and site (Table 3).

balance_calculations.K_balance: Ranged from +856 to -2376 kg K/ha over 21 years (Table 3). Only the full FYM treatment had a positive balance.

data_collection_schedule: Final soil samples after harvest in 2017.
study_timeline.monitoring_frequency: Annual for yields, start and end points for detailed soil analysis in this paper.

long_term_trends.trend_units: kg K/ha (Mehlich 3) over 21 years in N-only treatment at Humpolec
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Fertilization strategies with negative K balance lead to depletion of bioavailable soil K pools.

Soils with low Kne reserves (like Luvisol at Hněvčeves) are susceptible to depletion under K-mining practices. Soils with high Kne reserves (like Cambisol at Humpolec) can buffer K removal for longer periods.

variability_characterization.inter_annual_variability: Mentioned in the context of precipitation influencing K uptake.
variability_characterization.spatial_variability: A key focus of the study, comparing two sites with different soil types and climate, which showed significant differences in K dynamics, especially non-exchangeable K.
variability_characterization.measurement_uncertainty: Indicated by letters for statistical significance in figures.

methodological_strengths: Long-term study (21 years) providing insights into slow processes.
Comparison of two contrasting sites (soil and climate).
Comprehensive set of fertilization treatments, including control, organic, and mineral options.
Analysis of multiple soil K fractions (bioavailable, exchangeable, non-exchangeable).
methodological_limitations: Soil analyses for this paper were based only on samples from plots with spring barley, not all three crops in the rotation.
Potassium balance calculation did not consider K contribution from the subsoil.
Atmospheric deposition of K was not included in the balance calculation (though likely small).
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: The paper provides detailed data for the specified objectives, including inputs, outputs, and changes in soil K pools.

measurement_precision.soil_K: Statistical significance between treatments is provided, but standard errors or confidence intervals are not explicitly listed in tables/text.

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Two sites representing different conditions within the Czech Republic.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: 21-year duration is robust for assessing long-term trends.
representativeness.system_representativeness: Stated to be representative of intensive farming systems in the Czech Republic.

uncertainty_sources: Assumption that K dynamics under spring barley represent the entire rotation.
Exclusion of subsoil K from balance calculations.
validation_evidence: Results are compared with findings from other well-known long-term experiments (e.g., Rothamsted, Bad Lauchstadt).

key_methodological_references.citation: Haby V.A., Russelle M.P., Skogley E.O. (1990)
key_methodological_references.topic: Ammonium acetate extraction for exchangeable K
Boiling HNO3 extraction for non-exchangeable K

comparative_studies.topic: K balance and content in European long-term experiments
Long-term effects of fertilizer, straw, and manure
K release and balance in a long-term experiment in India

literature_integration.theoretical_framework: The study is based on the concept of potassium balance (inputs vs. outputs) and the dynamics between different soil potassium pools (solution, exchangeable, non-exchangeable) in response to agricultural management.
benchmarking_data: Non-exchangeable K values were compared to those from Bad Lauchstadt and Rothamsted experiments.

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: The paper is rich in quantitative data regarding potassium dynamics, soil properties, and agricultural management over a long-term period.
potential_ambiguities: The exact values for each treatment in the figures had to be estimated from the graphs or inferred from text descriptions, as they were not provided in a table.
The significance level for the correlation at the Humpolec site was not explicitly stated but inferred to be high.
extraction_limitations: The provided OCR of figures was unusable and ignored; data was taken from the text and visual inspection of the figures.
Standard errors for most mean values are not provided in the paper.
recommended_validation_checks: Confirm the regression significance for the Humpolec site if access to supplementary data is possible.

results.paper_id: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments.pdf
